explanation:
Provide the following so the next analyst can determine whether any of the controlling expressions in UT_BSP_DoText are invariant (MISRA rule):

- BSP_UT_Global
  - Need the struct/variable declaration to know whether it (or its fields) is const/volatile or modifiable at runtime. Invariance of expressions that use CurrVerbosity depends on whether BSP_UT_Global is truly constant.

- BSP_UT_Global.CurrVerbosity
  - The code computes MsgEnabled = CurrVerbosity >> MessageType. To decide if (MsgEnabled & 1) or (MsgEnabled <= 1) is invariant we must know the type, initial value (if any), and whether the value can change at runtime (volatile, updated elsewhere). This field directly determines those controlling expressions.

- UTASSERT_CASETYPE_* (ABORT, FAILURE, MIR, WARN, TSF, TTF, BEGIN, PASS)
  - The switch on MessageType and the later equality check (MessageType == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT) depend on these constants. To see if a switch-case or final if is an invariant (e.g., MessageType always equal to one value), the actual numeric values and any guarantees about MessageType usage are required.

- OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_* (NORMAL, HIGHLIGHT, RED, GREEN, BLUE)
  - TermModeBits is compared against OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL and assigned combinations of these constants. To determine whether the comparisons (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL) are invariant in any path, the numeric values and whether they are macros/consts are needed (and whether any of them are volatile or can change).

Rationale summary: the potential MISRA violation would arise if any controlling expression is provably invariant at compile/run time. The controlling expressions to check are: (MsgEnabled & 1), (MsgEnabled <= 1), the switch(MessageType) cases, (TermModeBits != OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL), and (MessageType == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT). The listed symbols are the minimal set required to determine whether those expressions can be invariant (constant, compile-time, or otherwise unchanging) under the build/runtime model.
